articles.title: Supreme Court Snubs Martin Shkreli‚Äôs Last-Ditch Bid to Avoid $64 Million Fine
articles.description: There were no generic alternatives to a lifesaving drug when Shkreli jacked up its price by more than $700 per pill in 2015.
articles.content:
Martin Shkreli has been fighting a $64.6 million fine he acquired in 2022 for blocking affordable alternatives to Daraprim, a lifesaving antiparasitic drug. Shockingly, it turns out nobody on the Supreme Court cares to hear about it. No justices dissented on Monday when the court said it declined to hear an appeal by representatives of the former pharmaceutical executive. In a last-ditch effort, Shkreli‚Äôs lawyers asked the Supreme Court to resolve conflicting rulings after the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the $64.6 million order and a lifetime ban to block Shkreli from working in the drug business. Only, the conflicting rulings didn‚Äôt even exist, New York Attorney General Letitia James argued in an August brief. The Supreme Court had nothing to add when it snubbed Shkreli. The so-called ‚Äúpharma bro‚Äù rose to infamy as the chief of Turing Pharmaceuticals ‚Äî later called Vyera. In 2015, the startup bought exclusive rights to Daraprim and jacked up its price from $13.50 to $750 a pill. At the time, there were no generic alternatives to the toxoplasmosis medication, which is used to treat a rare condition that affects pregnant people, babies, and people with HIV and cancer. Shkreli, also temporarily the owner of a secret Wu-Tang Clan album, was convicted of securities fraud and sentenced to seven years in prison in a 2017 case unrelated to Daraprim. In a comment to Gizmodo at the time, Shkreli said he planned to ‚Äúmake paper from inside‚Äù while serving time. Two years later, the former executive reportedly faced solitary confinement for trying to run a company with a contraband phone. Shkreli got out of prison in 2022 and promptly announced a Web3-based drug discovery venture called Druglike. His other recent projects include launching a medical chatbot called Dr. Gupta and taking credit for a cryptocurrency named after former President Donald Trump. Turing filed for bankruptcy and moved to sell the rights to Daraprim in 2023.

articles.title: Donald Trump‚Äôs iPhone Wallpaper Is Just a Photo of Himself
articles.description: Trump's narcissism knows no bounds.
articles.content:
It‚Äôs no secret that Donald Trump is a big fan of himself. Countless mental health professionals, and even fellow Republicans, have diagnosed the former president as a raging narcissist. But new photos that have been circulating on social media probably demonstrate Trump‚Äôs narcissism in the most direct way possible. Trump‚Äôs iPhone wallpaper is just a photo of himself. The image on Trump‚Äôs phone homescreen appears to be a photo from July 19, 2019, taken while the neo-fascist grifter was occupying the White House, captured by Getty Images photographer Chip Somodevilla. Trump, who often criticized other presidents like Barack Obama and Joe Biden for taking too much vacation time, was ‚Äútraveling to New Jersey to host a fundraising dinner and spend the weekend at his Trump National Golf Club in Bedminster,‚Äù according to the caption from Getty Images. For context, the photo is from the height of Trump‚Äôs family separation policy for migrants, which forcibly separated children from their parents at the border, placing them in the same kind of camps Trump has sworn to bring back. When the photo was taken, Trump‚Äôs lawyers at the U.S. Department of Justice had just argued in court that the U.S. government had no responsibility to provide kids in custody with soap or toothpaste. They also argued that it was unnecessary to give migrants beds or cots while they slept on the ground in overcrowded government-run cages. You know, the good old days of Trump. The photos that reveal Trump‚Äôs wallpaper‚Äîwhich were posted to Reddit before being deleted on Tuesday for some unknown reason‚Äîshow Trump with a group of YouTubers known as the Nelk Boys. The men, who also host a podcast called Full Send, often pull pranks in their videos, like recently bringing a food truck to Springfield, Ohio, where they asked people to buy their dog and cat meat, a reference to the racist meme that Trump helped spread, falsely claiming that immigrants from Haiti were eating domestic animals. It‚Äôs not immediately clear where the photos of the Nelk Boys on Reddit may have originated since they don‚Äôt appear on the social media channels of the podcasters nor those of Trump or his immediate social circle, as far as Gizmodo can tell. Gizmodo only learned about this bizarre fact after reporter Karl Bode first pointed it out Tuesday with a post on Bluesky, but this wallpaper isn‚Äôt new, as we can see by parsing older photos and videos with Trump‚Äôs phone visible. Eric Schmitt, a U.S. Senator from Missouri who‚Äôs running for re-election this year, posted a photo with Trump on his Facebook page October 5 where you can also see Trump‚Äôs wallpaper. Schmitt was traveling with Trump to Butler, Pennsylvania, that infamous rally where Elon Musk jumped up and down, exposing his stomach and generally looking like a real weirdo. Schmitt is rumored to be on Trump‚Äôs ‚Äúshort list‚Äù for Attorney General. If you zoom in on the phone at the table you can see Trump has that wallpaper of himself pointing at the camera. It‚Äôs much more difficult to see than the images going viral this week on social media, but it‚Äôs definitely the same wallpaper. A video of Trump golfing in late 2023 clearly shows the former president‚Äôs phone with the bizarre wallpaper as well. Benny Johnson, a right-wing influencer exposed last month as having taken a lot of money for an political influence operation tied to the Russian government, posted the video of Trump‚Äôs golf cart to YouTube in Dec. 2023. The image is pixelated when you zoom in, but once you‚Äôve seen the photo in other places, it‚Äôs clearly the same one from 2019 that Trump has apparently been using as his wallpaper for some time now. Johnson even comments on Trump‚Äôs phone wallpaper in his video, and rather than seeing it as a sign of a very self-absorbed and sick mind, the 37-year-old influencer seems to love it. ‚ÄúDid you see Donald Trump‚Äôs phone there?‚Äù Johnson asks in the video. ‚ÄúThe background screen of Donald Trump‚Äôs phone is Donald Trump going like this. Donald Trump‚Äôs wallpaper is Donald Trump, staring down the barrel of the camera and pointing.‚Äù ‚ÄúBro! You love this guy more? He knows he‚Äôs the meme. And that‚Äôs where his power comes from,‚Äù Johnson continued. The former president is out on the campaign trail holding his neo-fascist rallies, posing for photo-ops in disaster zones, and promising to send the military after his political opponents on Election Day and beyond. Trump has made more than 100 threats to prosecute or punish his perceived enemies, according to a new tally by NPR. And yet Trump is still seemingly neck-and-neck with Kamala Harris in the polls. With just two weeks left until Election Day on Nov. 5, Harris is ahead by just 1.7%, according to 538‚Äôs national polling average. And the margins are even tighter in battleground states that Harris needs to win in order to secure the White House. In Michigan, Harris is up just 0.1%, while she‚Äôs up just 0.4% in Wisconsin. And in Pennsylvania, Trump actually took the lead in recent days, according to 538‚Äôs polling average for the state, up 0.4%, if you can believe it. Whoever wins those three states will likely win the presidency. Trump, the adjudicated rapist who‚Äôs been convicted of 34 felonies, somehow has a real shot at becoming president again. If that happens, Americans are clearly in for a lot of trouble. Because the narcissist-in-chief doesn‚Äôt care about anyone but himself, as evidenced by his iPhone wallpaper, among countless other facts. And he‚Äôs out to inflict as much pain as possible should he be given the reins of power again.

articles.author: Matt Novak
articles.title: Elon Musk Says He Might Get Thrown in Jail If Trump Doesn‚Äôt Win
articles.description: Musk also claimed liberal states were "making crime legal" during an interview with Tucker Carlson.
articles.content:
Elon Musk, the world‚Äôs richest person, appeared on a new episode of Tucker Carlson‚Äôs web video show Monday in an almost two-hour interview. Musk made false claims about undocumented immigrants voting in the U.S., lied about the state of California legalizing theft, and complained about homeless people, among a host of other topics. Musk even claimed‚Äîfirst jokingly and then not-so-jokingly‚Äîthat he would be thrown in prison if Donald Trump didn‚Äôt beat Kamala Harris in the presidential election. ‚ÄúIf he loses, man, what‚Ä¶‚Äù Carlson said with a laugh, ‚Äúyou‚Äôre fucked, dude.‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôm fucked. If he loses, I‚Äôm fucked,‚Äù Musk said as they both laughed. ‚ÄúHow long do you think my prison sentence is going to be? Do you think? Will I see my children? I don‚Äôt know.‚Äù Musk went on to explain that he‚Äôd been ‚Äútrashing Kamala non-stop,‚Äù notably mispronouncing the name of the vice president, while outlining the ‚Äújoke‚Äù he‚Äôd told on his social media platform X about the potential assassination of Joe Biden and Kamala Harris. Musk eventually deleted that tweet. It was all done with a laugh, but the discussion was also deadly serious, as viewers would learn while the two men spoke at length. Later in the interview, which was recorded on Sunday, Musk reiterated that he was such a threat to Democrats like Harris would even have him jailed. The billionaire said X in particular, which Musk bought for $44 billion back in 2022 when it was known as Twitter, was such a threat that Dems would try to ‚Äúshut it down by any means possible.‚Äù ‚ÄúThey‚Äôll try to prosecute the company, prosecute me. I mean, the amount of lawfare that we‚Äôve seen taking place is outrageous,‚Äù said Musk. Musk has very publicly backed Trump in this election and even started a Political Action Committee that‚Äôs offering $47 to registered voters in seven states who sign up for his ‚Äúpetition.‚Äù But Musk appears to think of himself as a perpetual victim of liberal forces, despite being the wealthiest person in the world. The billionaire SpaceX CEO also repeated lies about the state of California making theft legal, a right-wing meme that‚Äôs popular on X, which would seem to contradict his own assertion that he would eventually be thrown in prison for crimes if the Democrats remain in the White House. ‚ÄúWell, you know this whole movement to decriminalize crime,‚Äù Musk asked Carlson. ‚ÄúOh, I‚Äôve noticed. Yes. What is that?‚Äù Carlson replied. ‚ÄúMadness. Like to make crime‚Ä¶ crime legal, like in California you can just steal things and nobody does anything. It‚Äôs like fully legal to steal anything under $1,000 in California,‚Äù Musk insisted. Musk is referring to the fact that the cut-off for when a misdemeanor becomes felony theft is $950 in California. But as Washington Post criminal justice reporter Radley Balko wrote in 2023, debunking this meme, 34 states have a higher threshold for felony theft than California. Republican-run states like Texas ($2,500) and South Carolina ($2,000) have much higher thresholds, which undercuts this idea, despite what gets parroted non-stop on Fox News and X. Musk also complained that the public hasn‚Äôt seen deceased pedophile Jeffrey Epstein‚Äôs client list, a particularly funny observation given the fact that Musk‚Äôs brother reportedly got set up with a girlfriend by Epstein in an effort to get close to Musk, according to a 2020 report from Business Insider. Musk compared the number of clients we know about to the number of people who‚Äôve been prosecuted for Trump‚Äôs failed coup attempt on January 6, 2021, calling them ‚Äúprotesters‚Äù despite the fact that they were trying to stop the certification of the election so that Trump could remain in power illegally. ‚ÄúI mean they put like, whatever, five or six hundred January 6th protesters in prison and not one person on the Epstein client list,‚Äù Musk said, before Carlson asked if the list will ever come out. ‚ÄúYou know, I think part of why Kamala‚Äôs getting so much support,‚Äù Musk said, ‚Äúif Trump wins, that Epstein client list is going to become public.‚Äù Carlson then asked Musk ‚Äúdo you think Reid Hoffman is uncomfortable?‚Äù referring to the billionaire co-founder of LinkedIn, who had visited Epstein‚Äôs private island in the Caribbean in 2014, according to a 2023 report from the Wall Street Journal. Hoffman told the newspaper that he was on an ‚ÄúMIT fundraising trip‚Äù at the time. Musk replied by saying that he did think Hoffman is uncomfortable along with ‚ÄúGates,‚Äù presumably referring to Bill Gates, who also met with Epstein at least three times, according to reporting from the New York Times. Musk also noted with a laugh that Hoffman ‚Äúwas my vice president of business development at PayPal.‚Äù But, again, if any association with Epstein and his accomplice Ghislaine Maxwell is something to be worried about we have some bad news for both Musk and Donald Trump. Carlson also claimed during the interview that rooms at Epstein‚Äôs homes were wired for video, suggesting any tapes could be implicating powerful people, though it‚Äôs not actually clear if such tapes exist. And Musk took the opportunity to pivot to talking about Sean Diddy Combs, who was recently arrested over sex trafficking charges. ‚ÄúWhere‚Äôs the video? I mean, between Diddy and Epstein, there‚Äôs probably several thousand hours of footage here,‚Äù Musk said. But, again, that‚Äôs an odd thing to bring up given reports that Musk has said he‚Äôs ‚Äúgood‚Äù friends with Diddy, who was also an investor who helped Musk take Twitter private in 2022. Is it possible Trump could actually release new information about Epstein? The former president was asked about whether he‚Äôd release any potential client lists on the Lex Fridman podcast last month. And his response was very odd. ‚ÄúUm, he was a good salesman. He was, you know, a hale and hearty type of guy,‚Äù Trump told Fridman before suggesting he might release files on Epstein without saying anything definitive. It was Trump‚Äôs own Labor Secretary Alexander Acosta who, as a U.S. Attorney in 2007, gave Epstein a sweetheart plea deal that provided the pedophile with immunity. And Trump defended Acosta at the time back in 2019 when people were calling for Acosta to be fired after new Epstein revelations came out. And don‚Äôt forget what Trump said of Epstein in a 2002 article for New York magazine. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve known Jeff for fifteen years. Terrific guy,‚Äù Trump is quoted as saying. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a lot of fun to be with. It is even said that he likes beautiful women as much as I do, and many of them are on the younger side. No doubt about it‚ÄîJeffrey enjoys his social life.‚Äù The rest of Carlson‚Äôs interview includes the usual whining from Musk about how the Democrats are trying to rig the election. Musk ranted about illegal immigration, claiming that Democrats are flying undocumented migrants into swing states to change the election. Musk also said the Dems will ‚Äúlegalize so many illegals that are there that the next election, there won‚Äôt be any swing states.‚Äù Musk even said that because Kamala Harris didn‚Äôt go through the traditional primary process before President Biden stepped aside, the Democrats were creating a ‚Äútiny oligarchy,‚Äù which is a funny thing for an American oligarch to say. Musk‚Äôs companies have literally made billions from U.S. government contracts and subsidies for SpaceX and Tesla, but the billionaire flatly denied that this was the case. The exchange is so unbelievable it‚Äôs worth quoting at length: Musk: There‚Äôs this total misunderstanding that my companies have been subsidized and supported by the government and get all these‚Äîand it‚Äôs like, do you really think that a Biden administration is going to subsidize me? Carlson: Probably not. Musk: In fact, they take away every contract they possibly can. So, for example, there was the FCC contract to $42 billion for providing rural broadband. Carlson: Yes. Musk: Okay. We actually first said, look, we think there shouldn‚Äôt be any subsidies, so we recommend that this program just not exist. But since you‚Äôre insisting that it exists, we will compete. And we have better products, so we won, I don‚Äôt know, about a quarter of it, which would have included the devastated areas like North Carolina and so on. And the FCC took it away illegally. They just voted‚Äîthree out of five commissioners voted away and said, even though you won it, we‚Äôre rescinding it. Carlson: On what grounds? Musk: And do you know how many people they‚Äôve connected? Carlson: How many? Musk: Zero. Carlson: So, you think that was political? Musk: Well, the three Democrats voted against it. And the two Republicans voted for it. The FCC didn‚Äôt immediately respond to questions emailed on Monday. The FCC program he‚Äôs referring to was a contract awarded in 2020 that provided SpaceX with $885.5 million in subsidies to deploy Starlink internet satellite service. The FCC cut off SpaceX in August 2022 citing poor speed test data, according to Reuters. But, to be clear, Musk‚Äôs companies have all profited handsomely from government money, even if SpaceX is currently having a tiff over one contract. And it‚Äôs frankly unbelievable that his company would try to tell the government a program shouldn‚Äôt exist and then bid on it. But none of that stopped Musk from saying some of the most ridiculously over-the-top things about what will happen if Harris wins on November 5. ‚ÄúMy view is, is that if Trump doesn‚Äôt win this election, it‚Äôs the last election we‚Äôre going to have,‚Äù Musk insisted. ‚ÄúThat the Democrats, the Dem machine has been importing so many people‚Ä¶ bringing in so many illegals‚Ä¶ flying, flying in with this like CVP [sic] border app thing that nobody even knew about like a secret program. That‚Äôs illegal basically.‚Äù Musk was referring to the CBP One app, which allows immigrants to apply for asylum. And while both Musk and Trump have tried to say this app is Biden‚Äôs doing, that couldn‚Äôt be further from the truth. Right there on the Customs and Border Protection website, you can see the app was launched in October of 2020. And you may recall that Trump was president at that time. Elon Musk is all in. (0:00) Elon Musk Is All in on Donald Trump(6:35) Providing Starlink to Victims of Hurricane Helene(9:22) If Trump Loses, This Is the Last Election(21:49) The Epstein and Diddy Client List(33:38) Vaccines(35:49) The Movement to Decriminalize Crime‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/jNqB1ThqQz ‚Äî Tucker Carlson (@TuckerCarlson) October 7, 2024  Musk, who‚Äôs worth about $264 billion, also complained about homeless people during his interview with Carlson, another very wealthy man. ‚ÄúHomeless is a misnomer. It implies that someone got a little behind on their mortgage and if you just offer them a job, they‚Äôd be back on their feet,‚Äù said Musk. ‚ÄúBut if you go and look at downtown Philly or San Francisco or parts of New York and actually most downtown, what you actually have are violent drug zombies.‚Äù Musk, who called Trump ‚Äúthe underdog,‚Äù also claimed that there are more billionaires in the Democratic camp than in the Republican camp. Forbes, the leading news outlet with expertise on the ways of the wealthy, actually conducted a survey of American billionaires in 2020 and found that 43% identified as Republicans, 33% identified as Democrats, and 24% identified as Independents. Yet again, Musk is full of shit. Carlson, whose father was America‚Äôs top foreign propagandist during the Reagan administration in the 1980s, also discussed George Soros, who Musk said wasn‚Äôt really in charge of the left-wing political machine to ‚Äúlegalize crime‚Äù anymore. Instead, Musk blamed that on his son, Alex Soros. Carlson said their policies were ‚Äúexpressions of hatred toward the United States.‚Äù ‚ÄúIf I was pushing that on a country, I would only do that if I hated the country and wanted to destroy it,‚Äù Carlson said. Musk, who refers to himself as ‚Äúculturally Christian,‚Äù also rambled about what he calls the ‚Äúwoke mind virus‚Äù which he claims is a replacement for religion and is waging a ‚Äúwoke holy war‚Äù that‚Äôs ‚Äúhighly resistant to change.‚Äù Musk launched into his theories on overpopulation and that people should be having as many kids as possible. ‚ÄúWe need to stop scaring women that having a kid destroys your life,‚Äù Musk said. ‚ÄúThis is false. We terrify girls into saying that if you get pregnant it‚Äôs your life‚Äôs over. This is what schools teach. I agree we should not have teenage pregnancies, but actually having a child is one of the most delightful, happiness-inducing things you can possibly do.‚Äù The billionaire was also railing against hormonal birth control for women, saying it ‚Äúcauses depression,‚Äù and suicidal thoughts while ‚Äúchanging their preferences for who they want to marry or have kids with,‚Äù insisting that ‚Äúit changes their personality.‚Äù Musk also called SSRI anti-depressants ‚Äúthe devil‚Äù that ‚Äúzombifiy people,‚Äù with Carlson even suggesting it has something to do with America‚Äôs mass shooting epidemic. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not saying no one should ever be subscribed [sic] SSRIs, but giving them out like candy is easy,‚Äù said Musk. Musk then segued into hyping AI, claiming generative AI could write ‚Äúa better essay than 95% of all humans,‚Äù and better images than ‚Äú90% of artists,‚Äù calling it just ‚Äúobjectively the case.‚Äù The billionaire also whined about OpenAI‚Äôs Sam Altman, who he‚Äôs had bad blood with ever since Musk was pushed out of the organization. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt trust Sam Altman, and I don‚Äôt think we want to have the most powerful AI in the world controlled by someone who is not trustworthy,‚Äù said Musk. The whole interview was just ridiculous and cringe-worthy all around. Musk told Carlson that he didn‚Äôt even have a teleprompter when he delivered his speech at a recent Trump rally over the weekend. Carlson looked incredibly impressed, which is hilarious if you actually watched Musk‚Äôs embarrassingly bad performance. It was incredibly clear Musk was winging it because he constantly repeated himself and didn‚Äôt have anything interesting to say. Instead, his painfully awkward jumping became the story of the event.

articles.title: Justice Department Says It Has Received Complaints About Elon Musk‚Äôs $1 Million Payments to Voters
articles.description: Is the tech billionaire breaking the law? We may soon find out.
articles.content:
Despite the fact that it is illegal in the U.S. to pay someone to vote, not vote, or register to vote, Elon Musk has been making it rain on the American electorate. It all started approximately two weeks ago when the billionaire began offering registered voters in swing states payments of $47. What for? To recruit other voters to sign a vague petition ‚Äúto support the Constitution.‚Äù Nothing wrong with that, right? Well, except for the fact that we‚Äôre in the middle of a fraught presidential election and Musk has been doing everything in his power to get one candidate (Donald Trump) elected. Getting elected requires voters and, to vote, you need to be registered to vote. Given this context, some might argue (and have argued) that Musk is financially incentivizing voter registration. Not long after his initial $47 offering, Musk upped the payment to $100. Then, several days ago, Musk escalated things drastically. He announced that, every single day until the election, he will give away a million dollars to a registered swing state voter who signs his petition. As of this writing, Musk has already doled out two $1 million payments to individual voters. Critics have maintained that Musk is basically trying to buy votes for Trump, or is running a paid voter registration drive, both of which would be against the law. One political science scholar, UCLA‚Äôs Rick Hasen, claims Musk‚Äôs activities constitute ‚Äúclearly illegal vote-buying.‚Äù Now, Justice Department officials confirm they have received complaints about Musk‚Äôs lottery-style giveaways, though it‚Äôs unclear whether they plan to do anything about it. On Monday, the Washington Post reported that a number of former Republican officials sent a letter to Attorney General Merrick Garland, asking the Justice Department to look into Musk‚Äôs payments to voters. The letter was signed by a number of former highly-placed officials, including former governor of New Jersey Christine Todd Whitman, former special adviser to Vice President Olivia Troye, and former chairman of the Federal Election Commission Trevor Potter, among others. The letter was also addressed to numerous district attorneys in Pennsylvania. ‚ÄúWe are aware of nothing like this in modern political history,‚Äù the letter states, in reference to Musk‚Äôs payments. ‚ÄúWe urge you to investigate whether America PAC‚Äôs payments are prohibited payments for voter registration. We recognize that they are framed as payments for signing a petition, or for referring voters who sign. But many of the payments are restricted to registered voters, so anyone who wishes to get paid must first register.‚Äù Were Musk found guilty of such a crime, he could spend up to five years in prison. Gizmodo reached out to Musk via Tesla. We also reached out to the Justice Department. A source familiar with Musk‚Äôs America PAC told CBS news: ‚ÄúThe PAC is confident in the legality of this initiative and the predictable media meltdown is only helping AmericaPAC‚Äôs efforts to support President Trump.‚Äù Musk has previously claimed that anyone (irregardless of political affiliation) can win his daily $1 million prize, so long as they sign his petition. Musk‚Äôs payments to voters obviously puts the Justice Department in a difficult position. We are a mere two weeks out from the election, which means that any effort to investigate or stop Musk could have a politicized effect. Should the government pursue action against Musk, it could easily be spun by Musk and other rightwing trolls as an attack on registered voters, who obviously stand to gain from the billionaire‚Äôs handouts. Musk, who has been running Trump‚Äôs canvassing operations in major swing states, has poured tens of millions of dollars into a campaign that is increasingly inventive and bizarre. On Tuesday, a new report claimed that Musk‚Äôs political action group, America PAC, had been buying ads for Donald Trump on Musk‚Äôs own web platform, X (formerly Twitter). Previously, America PAC has been criticized for a number of other issues and purported irregularities.¬†All of that said, the jury is still out on whether Musk is actually helping Trump win. Some high-level officials within the GOP have voiced concerns that Musk‚Äôs efforts aren‚Äôt actually all that effective. Previous reporting has suggested that the canvassing operations being manned by Musk-funded PACs are not making a dent.

articles.title: Jeff Bezos Reportedly Stops Washington Post From Making a Presidential Endorsement
articles.description: Newspaper endorsements don't matter much, it's the principle of management stopping them that matters.
articles.content:
Update 4:30 PM: The Washington Post‚Äôs Manuel Roig-Franzia and Laura Wagner have confirmed that the order to not endorse a candidate came from Jeff Bezos. Our original story follows below. The Washington Post won‚Äôt make an endorsement for president this year. Ben Mullin from the New York Times first reported the news, which was confirmed by CEO Will Lewis shortly thereafter. The announcement follows the same decision from the Los Angeles Times earlier this week, prompting a top editor to resign. David Shipley, the Post‚Äôs editorial page director, held a meeting with staff shortly before the announcement went out, a meeting which has been described as ‚Äútense‚Äù according to NPR. He told staff that he ‚Äúowns‚Äù the decision, and that the Post made the decision to stop endorsing candidates in order to create an ‚Äúindependent space‚Äù where the newspaper does not tell people who they should vote for. This is the first time the Post has not endorsed a candidate since 1988, though Shipley says the decision returns the Post to its policy in the decades prior to 1976. It began endorsing candidates again after the Post broke the Watergate scandal. Marty Baron, the Post‚Äòs legendary former executive editor, expressed his displeasure on X, posting: ‚ÄúThis is cowardice, with democracy as its casualty. @realdonaldtrump will see this as an invitation to further intimidate owner @jeffbezos (and others). Disturbing spinelessness at an institution famed for courage.‚Äù For his part, Jeff Bezos hasn‚Äôt addressed the situation publicly. His last public post on X came on July 13th, the day someone attempted to shoot Trump at a rally in Pennsylvania. ‚ÄúOur former President showed tremendous grace and courage under literal fire tonight,‚Äù Bezos wrote. ‚ÄúSo thankful for his safety and so sad for the victims and their families.‚Äù NPR‚Äôs David Folkenflik tweeted¬†that sources close to the matter indicate the decision was in fact made by Post owner and Amazon founder Jeff Bezos. Folkenflik says that Bezos hired the Post‚Äôs new CEO Will Lewis in part ‚Äúbecause of his pedigree in dealing with conservative power centers.‚Äù Shipley, the editorial page director, apparently approved an endorsement of Kamala Harris a week before Lewis made the decision to stop endorsements. Political endorsements made by newspapers like the Post probably don‚Äôt matter much, if at all. In today‚Äôs hyper-partisan world, the electorate are pretty hardened in their views and aren‚Äôt going to be swayed by a publication they are convinced is biased one way or another. An endorsement of Harris by the Post is just preaching to the choir. The bigger issue is‚Äîif it‚Äôs true that Bezos made the call‚Äîmanagement making these decisions from above rather than allowing editors to make the editorial decisions. The Post does have an editorial board, after all ‚Äî shouldn‚Äôt they be the ones making editorial decisions? There‚Äôs some logic in getting rid of an editorial board altogether and just having opinion writers articulate their views. But it‚Äôs odd for a newspaper with an editorial board to avoid making such a big decision right before the election. In the case of the LA Times, the decision to end endorsements was reportedly made by billionaire biotech investor Patrick Soon-Shiong, who has a history of intervening in the organization‚Äôs reporting. And the timing in particular is galling. Are these owners aiming to appease an antagonistic Trump in the event that he wins the presidency? We don‚Äôt really know, but newsrooms are supposed to be independent of management. Especially in the face of a candidate like Trump who speaks in falsehoods and poses a legitimate threat to independent media. Just recently he has said that CBS should lose its ability to broadcast on the airwaves over an interview with Kamala Harris that was edited, even though recent interviews of Trump himself have also been heavily edited. Looking at the Post under Bezos, his track record heretofore is pretty good. The newspaper has continued to critically report on Amazon and Bezos himself since he bought it, for instance. And Bezos did not do much to endear himself to Trump during his presidency. Trump ruthlessly attacked Bezos over his ownership of the Washington Post, in one instance seeking to jack up USPS shipping rates for Amazon in retaliation to unfavorable coverage (the company has been reducing its reliance on USPS). Bezos for his part kept quiet and allowed the tough reporting to continue. At the same time, billionaires like Bezos are often immune from real consequence, so it‚Äôs possible that he sees Trump in a different light than everyone else. Many of tech‚Äôs elites have been circling the wagons to support Trump‚Äîperhaps Bezos can compartmentalize attacks on the Post if he believes Trump would be better for tech and the wealthy elite. If he thinks Trump is going to win, maybe Bezos has made a calculated decision here to not poke the bear. We have reached out to the Washington Post for comment.

articles.title: Toho Animation Acquires Gkids and Aims to Bring More Japanese Media to the U.S.
articles.description: Godzilla Minus One and The Boy and the Heron's parallel Oscar triumphs apparently made the two want to go steady.
articles.content:
In the latest news of surprise business acquisitions and mergers that make sense at first glance, Toho Animation, the self-proclaimed leader in Japanese entertainment, has announced its acquisition of Gkids, a North American animation producer and distributor. Earlier today, Gkids published a press release¬†describing its acquisition by the Los Angeles-based Toho as one where Toho would acquire 100% equity from Gkids. At the same time, the other would maintain its independence (and folks in power as CEOs and whatnot) while utilizing Toho‚Äôs connections to bolster its commerce and further its reach in the entertainment world. What does all that mean to the average fan of Japanese entertainment and anime? Two mega powers in the industry are combining forces to compete against other companies that are jockeying for our precious attention, such as Disney. A key motivator behind Toho and Gkids‚Äô partnership is the winning success both companies experienced at the box office this past year with Godzilla Minus One and Hayao Miyazaki‚Äôs The Boy and the Heron. As Gkids states in its press release, both films earned significant achievements within a week of each other, with the former earning the highest box office revenue for a Japanese live-action film in the states and the third largest-grossing foreign film in U.S. history, and the latter becoming Studio Ghibli‚Äôs highest-grossing film in the U.S. And even beyond that, the two aren‚Äôt strangers to one another, having collaborated with the theatrical releases of animated films like Spirited Away: Live on Stage, Makoto Shinkai‚Äôs Weathering With You, and animation Studio Trigger‚Äôs Promare. Reading between Gkids‚Äô press release lines, the two likely decided to perform a fusion dance of sorts after making their presences felt during the most recent awards season (including the Oscars). To put one‚Äôs capitalistic cap on, the two aim to have their combined forces lead to a repeat of their individual successes with the aforementioned award-winning films as a united front. ‚ÄúGkids will continue to operate as we always have‚Äîwith the same team, the same passion, and the same mission‚Äîbut now with the backing of a highly complementary and legendary parent company,‚Äù Gkids founder Eric Beckman and president David Jesteadt wrote in a joint statement. ‚ÄúThis partnership will empower us to bring even more amazing films to North American and global audiences, while we continue to champion animation as a cinematic artform and push the limits of what the medium is capable of. We could not be more excited about the opportunities in front of us. The best is yet to come.‚Äù While Toho has become a household name for many an anime fan thanks to big marquee shonen series like Dragon Ball Z and Jujutsu Kaisen, Gkids has become a bit of a rising star in the cultural zeitgeist. Its North American theatrical distribution and home video releases of Look Back, Dan Da Dan, The First Slam Dunk, and Arcane season one are the most recent money-move examples of Gkids putting itself on the map for fans of Japanese entertainment and animation. Likewise, Toho has been on a future-sighted acquisition spree, recently taking on Scott Pilgrim Takes Off, Dan Da Dan, and Devilman Crybaby animation studio Science Saru. ‚ÄúThrough their hard work, vision, and integrity, Gkids has built a unique position in the U.S. market, which dovetails perfectly with Toho‚Äôs own strengths and strategic mission,‚Äù Toho president and CEO Hiro Matsuoka wrote in the press release. ‚ÄúThis partnership accelerates Toho‚Äôs goals to prioritize animation, develop international markets, and support IP creation, while bringing exceptional Japanese and animated content to global audiences.‚Äù Hopefully, this no-brainer acquisition doesn‚Äôt lead to an influx of layoffs across Toho or Gkids, as we‚Äôve seen countless times in the video game industry. In the meantime, the likes of Disney and Netflix can look forward to steep competition at both the box office and during awards season. Want more io9 news? articles.author: Matt Novak
articles.title: MAGA Election Official Sentenced to 9 Years for Giving Trump Goons Access to Voting Data
articles.description: The former county clerk suggested at her sentencing that God would get revenge against prosecutors because she's a "child of God."
articles.content:
Tina Peters, a former county clerk in Colorado, was sentenced to nine years in prison on Thursday for giving allies of Donald Trump access to voting data after the 2020 election, according to a livestream of the sentencing. Peters became a hero among Trump supporters for denying that President Joe Biden had rightfully won the election and was convicted for allowing a man to illegally access data from the Mesa County election system using a stolen keycard. Prosecutors in the case said Peters was intent on gaining fame for her loyalty to Trump, and was ‚Äúfixated‚Äù on the idea that the 2020 election was somehow ‚Äústolen‚Äù by the Democrats. There‚Äôs been no evidence of widespread fraud in the 2020 election after dozens of court cases brought by the Trump campaign, though the former president continues to insist he actually won. Working as the Mesa County Clerk, Peters used another worker‚Äôs security keycard and copied hard drive images from voting machines that were then presented publicly at a 2021 conference by Mike Lindell, the founder of MyPillow and a close ally of Trump. The defense argued that Peters was only trying to preserve election records, but that argument was unconvincing to a jury. Peters was found guilty in August on seven of the 10 counts she was originally charged with, according to the local ABC TV affiliate in Denver, including conspiracy to commit criminal impersonation, violation of duty, failure to comply with requirements of the Colorado Secretary of State, and attempts to influence a public servant. Peters spoke for roughly 42 minutes in a rambling and conspiracy-laden manner during the sentencing hearing Thursday and insisted that she doesn‚Äôt deserve prison time. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not a criminal. I have lived my life with honor and with honesty,‚Äù Peters said, according to a livestream from the courtroom available on YouTube. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt deserve to go into a prison where other people have committed heinous crimes.‚Äù Peters also said that she felt bad for prosecutors who were asking for a strict sentence because ‚ÄúGod doesn‚Äôt like people messing with his kids, and I believe I‚Äôm a child of God.‚Äù Peters insisted that she has medical conditions that can‚Äôt be treated in prison, and said she needed to sleep on a magnetic bed. Older Trump supporters have become rather notorious for their New Age medical beliefs, especially after ‚Äúalternative‚Äù medical treatments became popular on the political right during the covid-19 pandemic‚Äîtreatments like ivermectin, which they believe can cure the disease. Judge Matthew Barrett told Peters at Thursday‚Äôs sentencing that he was convinced Peters would try to do it all again in the pursuit of fame. Judge Barrett mentioned the perks that Peters enjoyed by becoming a kind of mini-celebrity within the Trump media ecosystem. ‚ÄúYou cared about the jets, the podcasts, and the people fawning over you,‚Äù Barrett said, according to a local NBC affiliate who was in the courtroom Thursday. ‚ÄúYou are a charlatan and you cannot help but lie as easy as you can breathe.‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôm convinced you would do it all over again if you could. You‚Äôre as defiant a defendant as this court has seen,‚Äù Barrett said. Bodycam footage from Peters‚Äô arrest in February 2022, which is available on YouTube, shows the confrontational arrest, where the former county clerk can be heard repeatedly shouting ‚Äúno, let go of me‚Äù and ‚Äúyou‚Äôre hurting me‚Äù at the arresting officers and claiming she would have bruising from being manhandled. At one point she also says ‚Äúshut up, what an asshole thing to say to me,‚Äù after an officer told her to stand up like an adult as she was being arrested. The entire exchange is rather remarkable when you remember that Trump supporters demand complete compliance with anything a police officer is saying and often blame those being arrested for ‚Äúresisting‚Äù arrest. The sentence of nine years includes two years spent in county jail and seven years in the Colorado Department of Corrections.

articles.author: Lucas Ropek
articles.title: Google Searches for Comedian Who Told Racist Jokes at Trump Rally Surpass Taylor Swift
articles.description: Who is Tony Hinchcliffe?
articles.content:
Not long after comedian Tony Hinchcliffe appeared at Donald Trump‚Äôs massive Madison Square Garden rally this weekend and called Puerto Rico an ‚Äúisland of floating garbage,‚Äù the internet came alive with Google searches for his name. In fact, as Nate Silver points out, searches for Hinchcliffe have eclipsed those for Taylor Swift. The obvious implication would seem to be that tons of people had no idea who Hinchcliffe was and were swiftly trying to ascertain the identity of the guy who had just insulted the island. Hinchcliffe‚Äôs comments have set off a political firestorm, with some commentators even questioning whether the viral remarks‚Äîwhich are sure to offend some members of America‚Äôs sizable Puerto Rican population‚Äîcould cost Trump the election. Problematically for the Trump camp, 2022 census data shows the U.S. has about 5.9 million people living in it that ethnically identify as Puerto Rican. Indeed, close to half a million Puerto Ricans live in the closely watched swing state of Pennsylvania alone. The viral joke had significant political after-effects, with numerous politicians‚Äîboth Democrats and Republicans alike‚Äîdecrying it. The Trump campaign has distanced itself from Hinchcliffe (a representative told Fox: ‚ÄúThis joke does not reflect the views of President Trump or the campaign‚Äù), despite presumably vetting his material before it went live. The joke also apparently inspired Puerto Rican rapper Bad Bunny‚Äîconsidered one of the most popular artists among Gen-Z Americans‚Äîto endorse Kamala Harris for President. In addition to outrage, Hinchcliffe‚Äôs joke seems to have inspired a lot of confusion‚Äîor at least interest‚Äîfrom droves of people, some of which had likely never heard of the comedian. Below is a screenshot of the parallel Google search stats of Taylor Swift and Hinchcliffe, with Hinchcliffe‚Äôs results represented in blue: Google Analytics related to Hinchcliffe shows some interesting regional metrics. In Florida, for instance, where some 1.2 million Puerto Ricans live, Hinchcliffe‚Äôs nationality was a top Google search. The Miami Herald, one of Florida‚Äôs largest newspapers, has reported that local politicians, including those who support Trump, have come out to decry Hinchcliffe‚Äôs comments. One U.S. Representative, Maria Elvira Salazar, of Miami, said she was ‚Äúdisgusted‚Äù by the joke. La Mesa Boricua de Florida, a Puerto Rican political advocacy group based in Florida, was quoted as saying: ‚ÄúTrump must not forget that in Florida around 800,000 Puerto Ricans have the ability to exercise their right to vote.‚Äù That said, Google Search interest seems to have been most heavily concentrated in predominantly ‚Äúblue‚Äù states, signaling that liberal denizens of those environs hadn‚Äôt heard of Hinchcliffe or his brand of edgelord-comedy. Searches were highest in Washington D.C., New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, and California. Hinchcliffe seems to be quite popular with certain demographics, as his podcast has nearly 2 million subscribers on YouTube. Hinchcliffe didn‚Äôt just belittle America‚Äôs island territory on Sunday. He also made a joke about a Black audience member and watermelon (‚ÄúLook at this guy, oh my goodness. Wow. I‚Äôm just kidding, that‚Äôs one of my buddies. He had a Halloween party last night. We had fun. We carved watermelons together‚Äù), shared his thoughts about the links between Hispanics, immigration, and birth control (‚ÄúThese Latinos, they love making babies too, just know that. They do. They do. There‚Äôs no pulling out. They don‚Äôt do that. They come inside, just like they did to our country‚Äù), and even dipped his toe in the Israeli Palestinian conflict (he referred to Palestinians as ‚Äúrock throwers,‚Äù and made a joke about Jews being stingy). Truly a cringe gauntlet of hacky material. The comedian‚Äôs racial comments have gotten him in trouble before. In 2021, he was ‚Äúcanceled,‚Äù after he referred to comedian Peng Dang‚Äîwho had introduced him at a standup event in Austin‚Äîas a ‚Äúfilthy little fucking chink.‚Äù Dang later told USA Today that he was offended by Hinchcliffe‚Äôs remarks: ‚ÄúTony never came up to me, talked to me or apologized. I don‚Äôt think he thinks that was offensive,‚Äù he said. Not long after the incident went viral, Hinchcliffe was dropped by his agents. Now, Hinchcliffe has his own podcast (Kill Tony) and has buddied up with podcast king Joe Rogan. Indeed, an old Rogan clip cirulated on X on Monday in which the podcast host suggested that Trump get Hinchcliffe to write him some jokes. It‚Äôs difficult to interpret what, exactly, the Trump campaign was hoping to accomplish with its MSG rally. In the mainstream media, the rally was widely referred to as a quasi-‚Äúfascist‚Äù invocation of the MAGA movement‚Äôs most odious tendencies. That said, lots of stuff has happened at Madison Square Garden over the years. Many presidents have held their rallies there, and Cyndi Lauper is set to play there later this week. Just because a big, loud political rally was held at New York‚Äôs premiere events center, that doesn‚Äôt mean it was meant to emulate the notorious pro-Nazi rally¬†held at the same location in 1939. Having said that, a whole lot of racist and sexist stuff got said on Sunday, and the overall tone (for this viewer, at least) really felt like one of swiftly encroaching darkness. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez has told multiple news networks that she feels the rally was an effort to rile up the uglier parts of Trump‚Äôs base. That seems like as good of a guess as any, though it also seems possible the campaign just saw it as another opportunity to produce viral content. Mission accomplished on that front, I guess.

articles.title: Disney Replaces Blade on Release Schedule with New Predator Movie
articles.description: Predator: Badlands will be out November 2025, plus 2028 just got three Marvel movies.
articles.content:
This might be the final stake in the heart for Marvel‚Äôs Blade. Previously scheduled for release on November 7, 2025, the Mahershala Ali vampire film has been removed from Disney‚Äôs release schedule. In its place is Predator: Badlands, the spiritual follow-up to Prey from director Dan Trachtenberg. In addition, Marvel dated three new movies for 2028: February 18, 2028; May 5, 2028;, and November 10, 2028. So let‚Äôs take these one by one. Pretty much everyone had a sense that Blade was not making its 2025 release date. Marvel already has three films coming out in 2025 (Captain America: Brave New World, Thunderbolts, The Fantastic Four: First Steps), all of which are well into production. Blade, as you may remember, lost its latest director Yann Demange back in June, which wasn‚Äôt the first time that happened. Being taken off the release schedule is never a good thing but it‚Äôs not necessarily the kiss of death. Sony did something similar with Spider-Man: Beyond the Spider-Verse and obviously that‚Äôs happening. It just means more time is needed. io9 reached out to Marvel and a source there reiterated what Marvel Studios president Kevin Feige has been saying for some time now: Marvel wants to make Blade, but it doesn‚Äôt want to make it just to make it. It has to be right and it doesn‚Äôt want to rush just to hit a release date. Scooping up that release date though is Predator: Badlands, the freshly titled follow-up to Prey from director Dan Trachtenberg and starring Elle Fanning. Previously, we‚Äôd just been calling it Badlands but now that it‚Äôs officially getting a theatrical release, we guess Disney added the franchise name on there (see also: Alien Romulus). The film was shot in New Zealand and, though it‚Äôs not a direct sequel to Prey, is expected to be in the same universe. It‚Äôs hugely exciting that after the success of Prey, Predator is coming back to the big screen for the holiday season. Back to Blade though. While the film is currently undated, Marvel did solidify its future with the same announcement. Those three new 2028 release dates (February 18, 2028; May 5, 2028; and November 10, 2028) could be anything, especially since they‚Äôre all in the aftermath of Avengers: Secret Wars in May 2027. Could one of them be Blade? The return of Deadpool? A second Fantastic Four movie? Young Avengers? We don‚Äôt know and we‚Äôre guessing not even Marvel knows for sure yet. But it now gives them seven ‚Äúuntitled‚Äù slots on the release schedule from 2026-2028. Marvel isn‚Äôt going anywhere, and maybe Blade will lead the way when it‚Äôs ready. Are you optimistic we‚Äôll ever see Blade? What are you thinking about the new Predator film? Let us know below. Want more io9 news? articles.title: SpaceX‚Äôs Dragon Capsule Can Now Land Like a Rocket in Case of an Emergency
articles.description: The crew capsule was always designed to land propulsively, but NASA felt more comfortable using parachutes for its astronauts.
articles.content:
Over the past four years, the Dragon spacecraft has returned eight NASA crews by performing a parachute-assisted splashdown in the ocean, but the crew capsule now has a backup landing method in the event of an emergency. SpaceX‚Äôs Dragon can land propulsively using its eight SuperDraco thrusters, a feature that was originally intended to be the spacecraft‚Äôs main way of returning to Earth but was later scrapped due to safety concerns. During the live webcast of the Crew-9 launch on September 27, NASA officials announced that in the event that all four parachutes fail to deploy, Dragon would land on a solid surface using the SuperDracos launch abort system. ‚ÄúDragon was always designed to land propulsively, but I didn‚Äôt want to risk it as the primary method,‚Äù SpaceX CEO Elon Musk wrote on X. During the early days of its development, SpaceX marketed Dragon‚Äôs ability to land using its eight SuperDraco engines, which would slow the spacecraft down during its descent until its velocity reached zero, at that point its landing legs would extend so the capsule can touch down on the pad. However, a lot can change in ten years. SpaceX‚Äôs Starship Looks Like an Alien Spacecraft as It Emerges from the Seafloor A few months after NASA awarded SpaceX its Commercial Crew Program contract, the company announced that its Dragon spacecraft would use parachutes to perform a splashdown with the astronauts rather than landing on a solid surface. It was later revealed that NASA felt more comfortable relying on the parachute landing system, according to NASA Spaceflight. The space agency also feared that the openings for the extendable legs could lead to the formation of hot spots during the spacecraft‚Äôs reentry through Earth‚Äôs atmosphere, which could cause the breakup of the crew capsule. During the launch webcast, Bill Gerstenmaier, vice president of build and flight reliability at SpaceX, noted that Dragons capable of making propulsive landing have flown on non-crewed missions before, but the Crew-9 mission marks the first time it‚Äôs being used on a NASA crewed mission. By now, NASA has plenty of reason to trust SpaceX and its ability to launch and return its crew of astronauts safely to Earth. The Dragon spacecraft that recently launched to the International Space Station is also responsible for bringing back two astronauts who had flown to orbit on board Boeing‚Äôs cursed Starliner spacecraft, which was later deemed unfit to return its crew back to Earth. That might have been why the Dragon spacecraft was finally allowed to keep its propulsive landing system handy in case of an emergency. ¬†

articles.title: Elon Musk Leaps Into the Meme History Books at Trump Rally
articles.description: Two photos from the event where Musk stumped for Trump became iconic fodder for the internet.
articles.content:
October has already been full of surprises this election cycle. But when Elon Musk announced he would join Donald Trump on stage Saturday at a rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, no one expected the billionaire would leap into the meme history books. Musk strutted on the stage with Trump while wearing black cowboy boots, a Texan-style belt buckle, an Occupy Mars T-Shirt, a black blazer, and a black MAGA hat. He was there to put juice behind his endorsement of Trump. ‚ÄúAs you can see I am not just MAGA‚ÄîI am Dark MAGA,‚Äù Musk said while whipping up the crowd. The Tesla CEO roamed the stage behind Trump and attempted to work the crowd like a professional hypeman while the former President gave a speech. Then, Musk leapt into the air, a serene smile on his face. AFP photographer Jim Watson snapped a picture at just the right moment to capture the whole scene. The blurred crowd, Musk seeming to float in the air, and Trump half turned towards his fellow billionaire with a sneer on his face. It was the stuff meme dreams are made of. #DorkMAGA #DorkElon pic.twitter.com/1m9AsWgnxb ‚Äî Barf üá∫üá¶üá®üá¶ (@PutlersPiss) October 6, 2024  Watson also captured the moment Trump and Musk shook hands. It‚Äôs an odd picture that shows Trump towering over Musk, who is reaching upward with his eyes almost rolled into the back of his head and a little grin twitching on his face. He looks like Grima Wormtongue pledging fealty to a liege-lord he plans to betray. the emperor: heaven has deserted me! The harvest is poor and the people are  in revolt all across the empire! All I have to rely upon is you, my trustworthy chief eunuch the chief eunuch: pic.twitter.com/HJa4iZatLK ‚Äî yoshimi the good soldier (@nise_yoshimi) October 6, 2024  ¬† On X, the site Musk purchased for 44 billion and is now worth considerably less, ‚ÄúDorkMaga‚Äù trended as users posted photoshopped Musk into embarrassing images and memes using Watson‚Äôs photos. The darkest, and most viral, was a picture of Musk leaping from the Twin Towers on 9/11. ‚ÄúImagine buying a website so people will think you‚Äôre cool and two years later people photoshop you jumping out of a window on 9/11,‚Äù Ela Bambust said in a post on X above the image. is this anything https://t.co/zF8kthiQlq pic.twitter.com/HhXRyVXqqQ ‚Äî Clarke (@pleasuresystems) October 6, 2024

articles.title: Russian TV Stations Down After Hackers Send Putin a Birthday Present
articles.description: Court websites and TV stations are down across Russia following a cyberattack that‚Äôs gone on for two days.
articles.content:
Some television stations and websites in Russia are offline for the second day in a row following what Moscow called an ‚Äúunprecedented‚Äù attack on its digital infrastructure. The disruption began on October 7, Russian President Vladimir Putin‚Äôs birthday. On Monday Russian state-owned broadcaster VGTRK‚Äôs website and digital streaming services went off the air. The affected outlets included radio stations and TV channels such as Russia-1 and Russia-24. ‚ÄúOur state media holding, one of the largest, has faced an unprecedented hacker attack on its digital infrastructure,‚Äù Kremlin spokesperson Dmitry Peskov said in a statement about the attack. VGTRK told Russian media that it had been attacked and was working around the clock to get services back online. ‚ÄúOn the night of October 7, online services of VGTRK were subjected to an unprecedented hacker attack,‚Äù it said in a statement. ‚ÄúSpecialists are working to find out all the circumstances, to understand where the traces left behind by those who organized this hacker attack on the critical infrastructure object lead.‚Äù As of this writing, the websites for VGTRK are still unresponsive. According to the Washington Post, state and local government-affiliated websites in Russia are also down. The Telegram channel for the court in the Vladimir region announced its websites were down for technical reasons. Courts in the city of Ufa postponed hearings. And courts in the Pskov region also announced they were delayed for technical reasons. A group of hackers calling itself the BO Team celebrated the hack on Telegram. ‚ÄúHappy Birthday dickhead,‚Äù BO Team posted, followed by four smiling poop emojis. A report in the Russian press didn‚Äôt name BO Team but, citing Russian intelligence sources, said that a group of hackers supported by the Ukrainian government was behind the attack. Kyiv has not claimed responsibility for the attack. Russia‚Äôs invasion of Ukraine was marked by an increase in cyber war on both sides. In 2015, Russia attacked Ukraine‚Äôs power grid with a Trojan virus called BlackEnergy. It tried something similar on Christmas the following year. Ukrainian-linked hackers have hit Russian TV stations multiple times with cyberattacks. On September 5 of this year, the U.S. government indicted five Russian GRU officers and one civilian, charging them with conspiring to hack the Ukrainian government. Picking Putin‚Äôs birthday to launch the attack is no coincidence. For decades, aspirants and detractors have used the Russian President‚Äôs birthday to get his attention and send a message. Putin‚Äôs perceived enemies tend to go missing or die around October 7. In 2006, famed Russian journalist Anna Politkovsk was assassinated in the elevator of her apartment. She‚Äôd been a fierce critic of Putin.

articles.title: Elon Musk Appears to Have Stopped His $1 Million Voter Giveaway
articles.description: Voter registration has closed in Pennsylvania anyway, so he probably doesn't feel a need to keep doing it.
articles.content:
Update: It appears we spoke to soon, as the America PAC announced another winner Wednesday night. Elon Musk‚Äôs PAC has been giving away a $1 million prize every day to a random registered voter in one of several swing states who sign a petition supporting the First and Second Amendments. The organization has also promised $47 to every registered voter who signs the petition. But it was reported yesterday that the Justice Department warned the group that the activity could be violating federal election law, and now it appears the giveaway has abruptly stopped. Axios reports that Musk‚Äôs America PAC, as the pro-Trump group is called, curiously did not announce a winner of the $1 million prize on Wednesday. Critics have said Musk‚Äôs giveaway was a thinly-veiled attempt at buying votes for Trump. The youth turnout in the U.S. is historically low, and the $1 million giveaway was only open to registered voters in states like Pennsylvania that could go to either candidate, suggesting that Musk was attempting to encourage the disillusioned to register‚Äîand return the favor of his giveaway by tipping the vote in Trump‚Äôs favor. Musk‚Äôs PAC The timing of the Justice Department‚Äôs warning was somewhat fortuitous for Musk. Voter registration closes in Pennsylvania‚Äîwhere he has been campaigning hard for Trump‚Äî15 days before the election, or October 21. So, Musk doesn‚Äôt really stand to gain much by continuing the giveaway at this point, and can stop doing it under the guise of the DOJ warning. He probably even considers the warning a relief. Musk has spoken about a potential Harris administration in increasingly alarmist terms, suggesting he would be thrown in prison if she wins the White House, and that ‚Äúhumanity will never reach Mars‚Äù under her guidance. These dark claims come despite the fact that Musk‚Äôs companies have grown tremendously under the Biden administration, with both SpaceX and Tesla receiving enormous support from the federal government and achieving momentous feats, such as the recent ‚Äúchopstick‚Äù Starship landing. Yesterday, Tesla reported earnings for Q3 2024 which included a windfall of $739 million in straight profit from selling EV tax credits to other automakers. Those tax credits, of course, are government incentives meant to grow the EV industry. Things at his privately held social media company are going less well. If we‚Äôre being honest, his hatred towards Harris and the Democratic party probably comes down to President Biden excluding him from the White House EV summit.

articles.author: Matt Novak
articles.title: Trump Supporters‚Äô Fake Stories About Harris and Walz Flood the ‚ÄòFor You‚Äô Page on X
articles.description: X has truly become a garbage heap since Trump donor Elon Musk bought the site.
articles.content:
The 2024 presidential campaign has been awash with fake stories about Vice President Kamala Harris and her running mate Tim Walz in recent months, all spread by supporters of Donald Trump. But nowhere are these stories more abundant than X, the social media platform formerly known as Twitter, which was purchased in 2022 by far-right billionaire Elon Musk. And we can probably expect the ridiculous lies to get even worse in the last two weeks of the campaign as Musk pours millions into getting Trump elected. What do we mean by ridiculous lies? Take a recent story that went viral on X, purporting to be a testimonial from a former student of Tim Walz. The person in the video, falsely identified as a man named Matthew Metro, claimed they were sexually abused by Walz. But anyone actually from Minnesota would immediately notice some big red flags. For starters, the person claimed they were a student at Mankato West, the high school where Walz worked in the 1990s and early 2000s. But the person mispronounces the word Mankato and somehow even the word Minnesota sounds weird. üö®BREAKING NEWS JUST ANNOUNCED:  Tim Walz's former student, Matthew Metro, posted a video online claiming he was sexually assaulted by Walz back in 1997.  If this is true, she's done. The Kamala Harris/ Tim Walz combo is done. It's over.#KamalaDumpsterFire pic.twitter.com/n6cgr70VrG ‚Äî Matthew Cottrell (@MatthewLovesUSA) October 17, 2024  Why was this going viral? Because it was being promoted by X‚Äôs algorithm in the For You feed, as I personally experienced on October 6. But the Washington Post spoke to the Matthew Metro, apparently a name identified by the disinformation agents through a publicly posted yearbook, who now lives in Hawaii. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs obviously not me: The teeth are different, the hair is different, the eyes are different, the nose is different,‚Äù the 45-year-old Metro told the Washington Post. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know where they‚Äôre getting this from.‚Äù Wired talked with analysts who believe the video is the work of a Russian-aligned disinformation operation called Storm-1516, which also spread the false claim that Harris participated in a hit-and-run in San Francisco in 2011. But Wired also believes the video was created AI, something that not all experts are agreed on. All we know for certain is that the video is clearly fake and is being spread inorganically on X. Or take the viral video purporting to be an explosive bombshell about the time cocaine was found at the White House. Previously right-wing actors insisted without evidence that the cocaine must have belonged to Hunter Biden, President Joe Biden‚Äôs son. But ever since Biden dropped out of the race in July, many of those same conspiracy theories have been repurposed to somehow fit Harris. The video is made to look like an undercover hidden camera expos√©, complete with night-vision green tinting, disguised voices, and a blurred face. But it‚Äôs all of these poorly executed details that make the video so obviously fake. For starters, if this was a real undercover video being shared by Trump supporters, why would they want to hide the identity of someone in the Biden White House, especially if the camera was ostensibly hidden? The creators mashed up two different techniques, undercover expos√© and identity protection, which simply doesn‚Äôt make sense for the ostensible reason behind this video when you think about the context of this video for even a second. So the cocaine in the White House was Kamala Harris‚Äôs‚Ä¶..  No wonder why Joe Biden is pissed‚Ä¶. pic.twitter.com/QSR3V9HdUh ‚Äî Zade Smith (@ZadeSmith4) October 3, 2024  There are also things about the video that are just laughably fake, like the crowd noises for what‚Äôs supposed to be a ‚Äúbar.‚Äù Cellphone videos have been around long enough now that we all know what background noise for various environments sound like on camera. And this one is clearly just an audio file of stock background noises laid on top. It‚Äôs pretty pathetic. The script is full of right-wing ways of talking about Harris, pointing out her laugh and other things MAGA faithful hate about the vice president. Even the visual elements are just clearly someone‚Äôs basement rather than an actual bar. An account with the name Zade Smith that uses what appears to be an AI-generated image for an avatar was one of many that helped spread the fake video, racking up over 2 million hits alone. There‚Äôs also a line that seemed to be popular and spread on X by various accounts in a coordinated fashion, logging millions of views for the claim, even without the video: ‚ÄúNew leaks indicate that it was Kamala Harris, not Hunter Biden who brought cocaine to the White House back in 2023.‚Äù Another story that went viral on X recently was the claim that a whistleblower with ABC News has tapes that would prove there was some kind of improper coordination between the Harris campaign and the news network before the presidential debate in September. The claim was started by an account known as ‚ÄúThe Black Insurrectionist‚Äù but after spreading far and wide, while the ‚Äúwhistleblower‚Äù complaint even included a poorly photoshopped ‚Äúaffidavit‚Äù swearing to the authenticity of the claims, which got X‚Äôs legion of Trump fans really excited. The whistleblower even sent a letter to Speaker of the House Mike Johnson, according to the Black Insurrectionist. But even right-wing influencers like former Fox News host Megyn Kelly had to admit it sounded fishy. And when Kelly reached out to Johnson‚Äôs office, they confirmed he never received any such letter. ‚ÄúWe are now able to confirm the speaker‚Äôs office did not get the letter,‚Äù Kelly wrote on her website. ‚ÄúWe have spoken with a source with direct knowledge who said Speaker Johnson‚Äôs office never received the document in question. Additionally, the alleged tapes have never been made public. The alleged whistleblower has never come forward. We were told he was possibly filing a lawsuit. That didn‚Äôt happen.‚Äù But that didn‚Äôt stop Trump from claiming collusion between the network and the Harris campaign. Whoever this supposed whistleblower was never came forward, obviously. And the original account that first spread this nonsense was deactivated by whoever was running it sometime around October 18, according to a BBC fact-checker. It really shouldn‚Äôt be any surprise that people who want to get Trump elected are spreading misinformation. They‚Äôve been doing it for years. The only difference is they‚Äôre now getting major support from Musk to make sure as many people as possible see their garbage on big platforms like X. For its part, the Trump campaign is also spreading fake news even in official campaign events. Over the weekend, Trump appeared at a McDonald‚Äôs location in Feasterville-Trevose, Pennsylvania where he claimed to be ‚Äúworking‚Äù at the restaurant. In reality, the McDonald‚Äôs location was closed and supporters went through the drive-thru line to make it look like they were surprised to find Trump serving food. The video from the event is much funnier when you know that context, as people in the various cars try to act shocked that Trump was there. It was all staged to the last person. Trump is also repeatedly spreading bullshit about everything from FEMA to immigrants, sometimes combining the two lies, like he did Monday during a photo-op in North Carolina. ‚ÄúNow, you know, in theory, they‚Äôre supposed to have it, but they spent a lot of money on bringing illegal migrants, people that came into our country illegally, to the United States,‚Äù Trump said, lying through his teeth, ‚Äúand taking them in, and all of the money they‚Äôve spent, numbers that nobody can even believe. So they don‚Äôt have any money for the people that live here.‚Äù Trump on disaster aid: They are supposed to have it, but they spent a lot of money on bringing illegal migrants.. so they don't have any money for the people that live here.. pic.twitter.com/o16iUBy76X ‚Äî Acyn (@Acyn) October 21, 2024  Trump has helped fuel conspiracy theories about Hurricanes Helene and Milton, which have both devastated people living in many southern states. But FEMA has dispersed millions in aid to people impacted by the hurricanes, no matter what Trump says. Roughly $1.8 billion in federal money for individuals and communities affected by both Helene and Milton has been approved by the White House as of last week. ‚ÄúFederal assistance for those affected by the hurricanes includes $597 million to support survivors with housing repairs, personal property replacement and other essential recovery efforts,‚Äù according to a FEMA press release dated Oct. 16. ‚ÄúAdditionally, over $934 million has been approved for debris removal and emergency protective measures, which are necessary to save lives, protect public health and prevent further damage to public and private property.‚Äù There are precisely 15 days until the election is held on Nov. 5 and many people are already voting. But the polling is so close that it‚Äôs clearly a toss up at this point between Harris and Trump. Again, we‚Äôre almost certain to see many more dirty tricks on X over the next two weeks. But voters need to take everything they see with a grain of salt, especially on social media platforms owned by MAGA billionaires who are donating $75 million and counting to Trump.

articles.author: Matt Novak
articles.title: Elon Musk Donates $75 Million to His Own Pro-Trump Group
articles.description: The Tesla CEO called his PAC "centrist" because you can just say whatever you want on the internet.
articles.content:
Elon Musk, a far-right influencer who also happens to be one of the wealthiest people in the world, formed a political action committee in May called America PAC, a group dedicated to re-electing former president Donald Trump. And the PAC‚Äôs quarterly filing with the Federal Election Commission was posted publicly late Tuesday, revealing Musk has donated almost $75 million since July 3. That sum makes Musk one of the biggest contributors to Trump-aligned propaganda groups in this election cycle. Musk responded overnight on X to news of his donations being made public that his America PAC, ‚Äúis just aiming for common sense, centrist values.‚Äù It should be noted, of course, that this is horseshit. It‚Äôs complete and utter horseshit, since Trump is a racist, convicted felon and sexual predator who dismantled abortion rights in this country and promises to be a dictator on day one. You know, centrist stuff. The Wall Street Journal reported back on July 16 that Musk was likely to donate around $45 million per month to his PAC, a claim the Tesla CEO initially denied. Musk tweeted a graphic that read ‚Äúfake gnus‚Äù about the initial report, leading many of his defenders to think he wasn‚Äôt donating anything. But that wasn‚Äôt the case, obviously.  pic.twitter.com/RJdF7MWeEi ‚Äî Elon Musk (@elonmusk) July 16, 2024  Musk later admitted he was contributing money to America PAC, just not $45 million per month. The billionaire didn‚Äôt elaborate, creating a guessing game for the general public as it became increasingly clear that Musk had inserted himself into the election cycle. Aside from promoting pro-Trump content on the social media site he purchased, formerly known as Twitter, Musk also appeared at an Oct. 5 rally for Trump in Butler, Pennsylvania, where he jumped around like an awkward toddler, exposing his stomach and generally making a fool of himself. But the day when we would finally learn how much money Musk had donated was inevitably going to come around. In reality, the tech mogul donated $14.95 million in July, $30 million in August, and $30 million in September, according to the FEC filing, totaling $74.95 million. The FEC filing covers donations from July 1 to Sept. 30, so it‚Äôs unclear if Musk has made any donations in the past two weeks. And while Musk‚Äôs initial donations weren‚Äôt reaching the level of $45 million per month, as the Wall Street Journal claimed, it was still a good chunk of money. Musk also knows quite well that this was the last FEC filing before the election on Nov. 5, so there‚Äôs plenty of time for Musk to inject more cash before any of it can be made public. Musk‚Äôs donations: What does all of this money get spent on? The group buys digital ads on platforms like Google, YouTube, and Facebook in an effort to convince people that Trump, a convicted felon and racist dullard, is actually the person who should run this country again. There are also a handful of ads for Republicans in very competitive House races. Some of the ads even feature Musk himself, imploring people to ‚Äúfight, fight, fight‚Äù and ‚Äúvote, vote, vote‚Äù for Trump, like in the ad below, one that‚Äôs currently running on YouTube. The Facebook ads are particularly embarrassing, given the fact that they promise anyone who requests a mail-in ballot for the upcoming election will get their name sent to Trump at his home in Mar-a-Lago. Some of the ads even refer to something called the 47 Club, a reference to Trump hoping to be the 47th president. ‚ÄúThe 47 Club isn‚Äôt for everyone. It‚Äôs an elite group Trump trusts,‚Äù the narrator says. ‚ÄúTo become a member, you must do one thing. Request a mail-in ballot. Once you do, your name is going straight to Mar-a-Lago. Vote by mail and save America.‚Äù The style seems to mimic the ‚Äúsecret‚Äù membership clubs promoted by toy and cereal manufacturers in the 1950s and¬†60s when¬†the target audience of Boomers were children. The implication is that Trump himself will see their name, though anyone who‚Äôs impressed by that transparently fake promise probably isn‚Äôt smart enough to sign their own name on a ballot, let alone operate a computer. America PAC also made headlines recently when it promised to give $47 cash to anyone who signs a ‚Äúpetition‚Äù in a swing state that pledges to support the First and Second Amendments. The ploy is clearly a way to collect personal information on voters in battleground states, though it‚Äôs not clear how many people have actually participated nor whether they‚Äôll actually get paid. It‚Äôs also unclear what the information will be used for this close to the election. The group also pays people to go door-to-door and ask them to vote for Trump. But new reports from the Washington Post and the Guardian about on-the-ground activities of the group make the entire endeavor sound like a disorganized shitshow. And that probably won‚Äôt come as a surprise to many people, given Musk‚Äôs reputation as a man who mismanages so many aspects of his businesses. America PAC reportedly pays workers between $20-40 per hour to knock on doors and convince likely Trump voters in crucial swing states to get out and vote early. But those workers appears to sometimes have bad info, according to the Post, often coming upon homes occupied by people who say they‚Äôll vote for Kamala Harris or undecided voters who are hard to persuade. The workers use an app called Campaign Sidekick which can be glitchy, as the Washington Post reports, and requires fast mobile connections to work as intended. That‚Äôs obviously a problem in more rural areas of battleground states like Wisconsin, where the Post spoke with a worker who was out knocking on doors. When a given worker doesn‚Äôt have a fast mobile connection, they‚Äôre supposed to use the app in ‚Äúoffline‚Äù mode, which presents even more challenges, according to the Guardian, since it doesn‚Äôt upload completed routes properly as the news outlet tells it. Tracking those routes is essential to ensure workers are hitting the right houses but also to guarantee efforts aren‚Äôt being duplicated. Campaign Sidekick didn‚Äôt immediately respond to a message Tuesday but pushed back to the Guardian against claims the app is glitchy, ‚Äúsaying it has always been upfront about the limitations of offline walkbook.‚Äù To complicate things further, the workers may not even be properly engaging people when they go out on their routes, according to the Guardian, with some staff just ‚Äúspeed-running‚Äù an assigned route and throwing campaign materials at the door without knocking. Workers are paid by the number of doors they knock, which creates even more bad incentives for people who may not be true believers in MAGA‚Äôs fascist cause. It all sounds like a mess, obviously. But that‚Äôs to be expected on some level with paid staff hired in a rush. And it sounds like everything really has been in a rush. The Post reports that some of Musk‚Äôs early political advisors warned him that he was trying to move things too quickly, given the time available before the election, ‚Äúcautioning that it would require months more to properly hire and train the necessary staff.‚Äù But doing things too quickly and trying to deal with the fallout is kind of Musk‚Äôs entire playbook, as anyone who saw the smoke and mirrors at Tesla‚Äôs big Cybercab event last week can attest. The newspaper also notes that Musk fired at least three vendors over the summer just as they were about to get started, making an already condensed timeline even more chaotic. And Musk has been micromanaging things in a frustrating way, according to multiple reports that date back to September. Musk endorsed Trump shortly after the former president was shot at during one of his neo-fascist rallies in Butler, Pennsylvania. And Musk has said that he believes Democrats will put him in prison if Trump doesn‚Äôt win, though it‚Äôs not entirely clear why he might think that. Musk also reportedly banned a reporter from X for releasing a dossier on JD Vance after the Trump campaign coordinated with the billionaire. That reporter has since been reinstated to Musk‚Äôs social media platform after the coordination became public. The race between Trump and Harris is still neck-and-neck if you can believe it, with FiveThirtyEight‚Äôs polling average showing Harris up just 2.4% in the national polling. Things are even tighter in the must-win states of Wisconsin, where Harris is up just 0.5%, Pennsylvania, where she‚Äôs up just 0.7% and Michigan, where she‚Äôs also up just 0.7%. It‚Äôs going to be a close one if the polls are to be believed.
